Albert Becerra Hervás
Alejandro Pérez Conesa

Daniel Egea Roca \nJosé A. del Peral Rosado

Whilst Carrier to Noise Ratio (CNO) depends specifically on the received satellite signal strength, the Automatic Gain control (AGC) defines the gain applied to received signals so that the power in the AC/DC converser is relatively constant. Therefore, if AGC and CNO levels are low, an external and stronger source of interference may be present.

This plot informs the user of Satellite contributions in terms of Carrier to Noise Ratio and geometry. Satellites with poor CNO or low elevations may introduce severe errors in user’s position. Thus, masks based on this metrics are applied to avoid their contribution in the Positioning algorithm.

The error plot displays the relative error between the Position derived from the App’s algorithm with the selected configuration and the Position provided by Google’s API. In this case, there is not a reference position as both algorithms perform differently depending on the user’s scenario.
A file with raw mesurements will be created every time you start computing if enabled.
